ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to apply math concepts to the real world. There were some really interesting units in the course, which I didn't even know was related to pre-calculus math.
I feel that I learned a lot of formulas and concepts that are applicable to real-life, which is a nice change from a lot of the other math courses that I have taken in the past!

I learned basic mathematics that I had previously been unexposed to in high school. Unlike many of my peers, I had a negligible STEM education in high school which has left me far behind my peers academically. This class gave enhanced my mathematical literacy.
I learned how to real world math. Really important things like calculating mortgage payments, loan/investment calculations, and more.

I learned a lot about applicable math to real word scenarios - just as the course advertises itself, and learned (shockingly as someone who has always been afraid of math) that it can genuinely be rewarding and fun! I loved this class and it was the perfect level of intellectual challenge, and I enjoyed exercising a different part of my brain than what I use for my major.

I learned lots of math that I had forgotten or did not know prior!!  I also discovered the beautiful benefits of attending office hours a very valuable college lesson.  I made lots of friends in office hours, got closer with my instructor, and my grade improved!
how to apply math in real world
I learned some fun math applications to real-world problems and situations.
I was re-introduced to Algebra, and introduced to finite math and statistics as well as modular arithmetic.

As the course name implies, I learned about math application in "real world" situations. For most of my academic career, I have struggled with word problems and being able to convert paragraphs into mathematical equations using critical thinking. Although I didn't initially realize it, this course is just that. I was forced to actually break down paragraphs and use my own intuition to solve equations.

I learned about math that will be useful to me in my future years, like interest, mortgage, and probability. This was a good course for me to take in my first semester at Yale because it wasnt too challenging but also just challenging enough.
real world applications of math.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Diethorn is a great lecturer and really takes time to make sure that everyone in the class understands the material. However, this also means that sometimes the pace of the class can be pretty slow. She also provides very helpful worksheets with practice problems and encourages collaboration with peers, which is great.
One strength was definitely the level of work--I feel like it was just enough to keep students really engaged and up to speed but never overwhelming!
Strengths: Really accessible content, really helpful professor. I liked having videos to watch ahead of time and going through assignments in groups/partners during class

The strengths the the course were its excellent professor Rachel and structure. Rachel is extremely kind and great at helping us master material we are scared to even look at at the beginning of a given class session. The class was very well structured to be challenging but not overwhelming, and the structure was adjusted based on how quick/slowly the students picked up different material, which I really appreciated. The group work time in class was also very helpful both for giving us one on one time to ask the Rachel questions and also time to work through problems with each other and form study groups that extended outside of class. The only weakness for me was that we spent our last class still learning new material for the final and I would have loved for that last day to be review.
I think this course was great Im not sure how it could be improved.  I think lectures could be made more engaging with a more direct connection to the real world?
very helpful professor

Strengths: Prof. Diethorn is a huge strength of this course. She uploads videos you can watch before each class with a quiz (that you can retake several times) that are really helpful. In class, she basically runs through the video material again, answers questions, and then allows you to work on practice problems in groups. She was super accessible in office hours. We also had a ULA who ran office hours once a week. She was really helpful when working on PSETs. Weakness: None.
Prof. Diethorn was amazing.  Her videos were a very good tool for me.  She was kind and quite helpful in class and office hours.

This course is designed in a way that students who follow the material should be able to do well on the exams. I liked the structuring of traditional exams instead of the midterm and then final (despite the fact that we did have a final) because it allowed for the content to be broken up into more digestible forms. I think that the final wasn't necessarily super helpful and took away from our final unit.

This course was very organized and the material was very helpful. I was able to learn about the different topics through different assignments that were given throughout the week. The instructor was very helpful and very engaging. I did not see any weaknesses with this course.
The professor was amazingespecially office hours. I did not think the pre-class videos helped much.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I definitely would! I would recommend it to non-math majors who want a better understanding of mathematic concepts that are useful in everyday life.
Absolutely!
Absolutely, Professor Diethorn is dedicated to the academic success of her students.
Yes! It was so helpful and addressed so many things I never learned in high school.

Yes! I would highly recommend this course to anyone looking for a QR credit because if you put in the work you will do well, and you'll have a fun and fulfilling time doing so! I'm not a math person by any means, but the kind and supportive energy created by my professor and peers helped me gain a new confidence.
For students who are not great at math and need a credit, i would definitely recommend this course to them.
yes very helpful for non math people

I would definitely recommend this course. Even if you are or aren't a STEM person, this course is interesting and fun! I learned new math topics and applications that were genuinely fun. Although the class was often predictable, Prof. Diethorn kept it entertaining and kept it moving.
I would recommend this course to any student who is looking to fulfill a QR credit. The work is manageable, especially with the great help the professor is in learning material.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to familiarize themselves with Math that is used frequently in non-math environments.

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. The content was explained each day in a way that was could be understood by almost anyone with a basic math education. While I was surprised by how traditional this course format felt (and how close it was to a high school style math class) it ended up being not so difficult to follow and enjoyable.
I would highly recommend this course to another student because it teaches you math that you wouldnt particularly learn in a regular math class. The instructor made the class very fun and engaging.
Yes, I learned a lot

extras.title: MATH 107 01 - Mathematics in the Real World
